name: Adams House
description: Named for Adams County, Pennsylvania.

name: Allegheny House
description: Named for Allegheny County, Pennsylvania.

name: Bard Hall
description: Built in 1961. Named for Judge Guy K. Bard, a 1913 and 1914 graduate of the normal school, who served in 1915 and taught mathematics and school management before serving as a public school teacher, an administrator, and a member of the Board of the Trustees of the normal school. He also served in several appointed state and national offices including Attorney General of Pennsylvania and U.S. Judge of the Eastern District of Pennsylvania. Originally a men's dormitory.

name: Bedford House
description: Named for Bedford County, Pennsylvania.

Office of Experiential Learning & Career.name: Office of Experiential Learning & Career Management

name: Biemesderfer Center
description:
Offices of the President; the Associate Provost for Academic.
Administration Built in 1895. 
Named for President D. Luke Biesmesderfer who served from 1943 to 1965 and his wife Elva, both 1917 graduates of the Normal School. 
The building is an excellent example of late Victorian architecture; it was originally built as the library and also served as the temporary union building (the 'TUB') before being renovated to its current use as the executive center. The H. Edgar Sherts Board Room, named for an 1896 graduate and prominent member of the Board of Trustees from 1910 to 1936, is located on the second floor.

Office of the Provost\/Office of Vice Pr.name: Office of the Provost/Office of Vice President for Academic Affairs

name: Biemesderfer Stadium and Chryst Field
description: Built in 1968. Named for President D. Luke Biemesderfer who served from 1943 to 1965 and was a 1917 graduate and President of the College.

name: Binns Room
buildingName: The Ware Center, Millersville University Lancaster

name: Bishop Service Building
description: Built in 1968. Named for John F. Bishop, who served from 1929 to 1957, former superintendent of grounds and buildings.

name: Boyer Building
description: Built in 1938. Named for Lee H. Boyer a professor of mathematics and head of the department. He served from 1934 to 1957. Originally designed as the boiler plant for distributing steam heat throughout campus.

Office of the Vice President for Informa.name: Office of the Vice President for Information Technology

name: Breidenstine Hall
description: Built in 1972. Named for Aaron G. Breidenstine, former Dean of Instruction who served from 1955 to 1966. It also houses the Swift Gallery, named for Margaret Swift a professor of art education from 1955 to 1966 and the Sykes Gallery, named for Ronald E. Sykes, a professor of art and former chairman of the Art Department who served from 1956 to 1999.

name: Brooks Gymnasium
description: Built in 1940. Named for Dr. Edward Brooks who served from 1858 to 1912. The building was originally designed as a health and education center containing the second gymnasium.

name: Burrowes Hall
description: Built in 1970. Named for Thomas Henry Burrowes. Burrowes was one of the founders of the normal school and a leader in the establishment of public education in the Commonwealth. The building was originally constructed as a dormitory for men.

name: Byerly Hall
description: Built in 1929. Named for Andrew R. Byerly, an 1855 graduate of the normal school, who served from 1858 to 1912 and was a member of the English faculty for fifteen years. The building originally served as the junior high school building for the community and laboratory school for the college.

name: Caputo Hall
description: Built in 1964. Roddy Science Center is named for Harry Justin Roddy, an 1881 and 1896 graduate of the normal school, who served from 1887 to 1926 and taught geography and geology and was also the head of the Science Department. The building also contains the Engle Physics Laboratory named for Daniel G. Engle, a professor of physics, who served from 1955 to 1974. Caputo Hall was constructed in 1999.

name: Chester House
description: Named for Chester County, Pennsylvania. Originally constructed as a single family dwelling.

name: Chryst Hall
description: Built in 1969. Formerly named the Stine Student Services Building for Clyde S. Stine who served from 1946 to 1968 and was the Dean of Men and a pioneer in student services at the college.

name: Columbia House
description: Named for Columbia County, Pennsylvania.

name: Commuting Students Association (CSA)/Lounge for commuting students
Cumberland House
description: Named for Cumberland County, Pennsylvania. Originally constructed as a private single family dwelling.

name: Dauphin House
description: Named for Dauphin County, Pennsylvania. Originally constructed as a family residence.

name: Delaware House
description: Named for Delaware County, Pennsylvania. Originally constructed as a family residence.

name: Diehm Hall
description: Built in 1964. Named for G. Graybill Diehm, prominent in Lancaster County and Commonwealth politics for forty years and who also held various elected offices including seats in both houses of the state legislature. Originally constructed as a dormitory for both men and women.

name: Dilworth Building
description: Built in 1963. Named for Homer F. Dilworth who served from 1912 to 1941 and was a professor of English and the first Dean of Instruction.

Office of the Vice President for Finance.name: Office of the Vice President for Finance and Administration

name: Dr. Charles R. and Mrs. Anita B. Winter Visual and Performing Arts Center
buildingName: Dr. Charles R. and Mrs. Anita B. Winter Visual and Performing Arts Center
description: Built in 1949. Named for Eliphalet Oram Lyte, an 1868 and 1876 graduate of the normal school, who served from 18?8 to 1912 and taught rhetoric, bookkeeping, pedagogy, and grammar before becoming Principal in 1887. A site of major cultural activities and various performances on campus.

name: Duncan Alumni House
description: Built in 1915, extensively renovated in 1990-1991. Named for William Duncan (former University President) and his wife Alma.

Office of Vice President for University.name: Office of Vice President for University Advancement

name: Dutcher Hall
description: Built in 1890. Named for former Dean Dutcher who served at Millersville from 1927 until 1952 and who was also a professor of social studies and chairman of the Social Studies Department. Served as the first gymnasium and later as the student union (the 'rat'). Houses 'The Rafter's' Theater.

name: Elsie S. Shenk Wellness and Women's Program
Environmental Hazards and Emergency Management Minor
Franklin House
description: Named for Franklin County, Pennsylvania. Originally constructed as a family residence.

name: Gaige Hall
description: Built in 1973. Named for Frederick Hughes Gaige, Director of the Training School and a professor of social sciences. He served from 1918 to 1939. Originally constructed as a dormitory for both men and women.

name: Ganser Library
description:
Built in 1967. Named for Helen A. Ganser who served from 1911 until 1952 as a librarian and also head of the Library Science Department.

Also within the building is the Ganser Art Gallery, and the Esther Risser Whitely Room, a reading room for Special Collections named for Esther Risser Whitely a reference librarian from 1952 to 1972.

name: Gerhart Hall
description: Built in 1961. Named for Arthur A. Gerhart who served from 1927 to 1955 and was chairman of the Natural Sciences Department.

name: Gilbert Hall
description:
Named for Sarah Hughes Gilbert, an 1877 and 1879 graduate of the normal school, who served from 1881 to 1912 teaching mathematics, then literature and elocution. 

Until 1964 it was known as Roddy Hall in honor of H. Justin Roddy and was a men's dormitory. It became a women's dormitory and the name was changed upon the completion of the Roddy Science Center.

name: Gordinier Hall
description: Built in 1966. Named for Charles H. Gordiner, who served from 1911 to 1929, who was also head of the Classical Languages Department and later Principal of the normal school and first President of the College. The four dining rooms were named for the following: Edna M. Kline, dietitian during the 1940' and 1950's; Milton C. Lehr, a manager of the college food services during the 1950's and 1960's; Elda M. McKee, dietitian during the 1940's; and Anne M. Mulcaster, dietitian during the 1930's and 1940's.

name: Grand Salon
buildingName: The Ware Center, Millersville University Lancaster

name: Harbold Hall
description: Built in 1964. Named for Peter H. Harbold, an 1898 and 1899 honor graduate of the normal school, who served in 1905, 1908, and 1912 to 1918 and was the Superintendent of the Model School and later the Principal of the Model School. Originally constructed as a dormitory for both men and women.

name: Hash Building/Bassler Hall
description: Built in 1900. Originally built as the Model School to serve pupils of the community as well as the students of the normal school. Formerly known as Myers Hall and named after Carrie E. Myers who served from 1893 until 1923 and was an 1884 graduate who joined the faculty and eventually became the Model School superintendent.

name: Hobbs Hall
description: Built in 1967. Originally built as a dormitory for women, it was originally Tanger Hall for Landis Tanger who was President of the College from 1929 to 1943.

name: Hull Hall
description: Built in 1966. Named for George W. Hull, an 1874 graduate of the normal school, who served from 1875 to 1921 and taught mathematics and was the head of the Mathematics Department. Originally constructed as a dormitory for both men and women.

name: Juniata House
description: Named for Juniata County, Pennsylvania. Originally constructed as a family residence.

name: Lebanon House
description: Named for Lebanon County, Pennsylvania. Originally constructed as a family residence.

name: Lenhardt Hall
description: Built in 1971. Named for Esther Lenhardt, a 1910 graduate of the normal school and professor of English and speech, later Alumni Secretary, and co-author of the Alma Mater of the college. She served from 1920 to 1966. Originally constructed as a dormitory for women.

name: Luzerne Building
description: Named for Luzerne County, Pennsylvania. Originally constructed as various apartments, a garage and a photo studio.

name: Lyet Lobby
buildingName: The Ware Center, Millersville University Lancaster

name: Lyle Hall
description: Built in 1949. Named for Anna Lyle, an 1866 graduate of the normal school, who served from 1873 to 1919 and taught elocution and history. Formerly a women's dormitory and dining hall.

Office of Experiential Learning and Care.name: Office of Experiential Learning and Career Management (ELCM)

name: Master of Science in Emergency Management
McComsey Hall
description: Built in 1970. Named for Sanders P. McComsey, a graduate of the college, served from 1927 to 1955, he was a professor of English, and Dean of Instruction and co-author of the Alma Mater of the college. It also contains the C. Maxwell Myers Auditorium, named for C. Maxwell Myers, a professor of social studies and chairman of the History and Social Studies Department. He served from 1941 to 1966.

name: Mifflin House
description: Named for Mifflin County, Pennsylvania. Originally constructed as a family residence.

name: Montgomery House
description: Named for Montgomery County, Pennsylvania. Originally constructed as a private single family dwelling.

name: Northumberland House
description: Named for Northumberland County, Pennsylvania. Originally constructed as a family residence.

Osburn Hall
description: Built in 1960. Named for Burl N. Osburn who served from 1932 to 1963 and was the head of the Industrial Arts Department and one of the organizers of the American Industrial Arts Association.

name: Palmer Building
description: Built in 1971. Named for A. H. Palmer, Superintendent of Grounds and Buildings. He served from 1912 to 1933.

name: Perry House
description: Named for Perry County, Pennsylvania. Originally constructed as a private single family dwelling.

name: Philadelphia House
description: Named for Philadelphia County, Pennsylvania. Originally constructed as a private two family dwelling.

description: Named for Pike County, Pennsylvania. Originally constructed as a family residence.

name: Potter House
description: Named for Potter County, Pennsylvania. Originally constructed as a family residence.

name: Pucillo Gymnasium
description: Built in 1971. Named for John A. Pucillo, professor and Director of Health and Physical Education, coach and Director of Athletics who served between 1925 and 1957.

name: Regitz Gallery
buildingName: The Ware Center, Millersville University Lancaster

name: Roddy Hall
description: Built in 1964. Roddy Science Center is named for Harry Justin Roddy, an 1881 and 1896 graduate of the normal school, who served from 1887 to 1926 and taught geography and geology and was also the head of the Science Department. The building also contains the Engle Physics Laboratory named for Daniel G. Engle, a professor of physics, who served from 1955 to 1974. Caputo Hall was constructed in 1999.

name: Schuylkill House
description: Named for Schuylkill County, Pennsylvania. Originally constructed as a family residence.

name: Stayer Hall
description: Built in 1964. Named for Samuel B. Stayer, a 1913 and 1914 graduate of the normal school, who served from 1916 to 1953 and taught mathematics, was Dean of Men, Director of the Training School, and head of the Education and Psychology Department. Originally constructed as a dormitory for both men and women.

name: Steinman Hall
buildingName: The Ware Center, Millersville University Lancaster

name: Student Memorial Center (SMC)
description: Built in 1971. Named in honor of all students, alumni, faculty, and staff who have served in the armed services of the United States.

name: Wickersham Hall
description: Built in 1938. Named for James Pyle Wickersham who served from 1855 to 1866 and was one of the founders of the normal school and its second Principal. This was the principle classroom building for many years.

name: Witmer Building
description: Built in 1968. Named for Dr. C. Howard, a 1902, 1903, 1904, and 1905 graduate of the normal school and a prominent physician in Lancaster County.

name: York House
description: Music faculty offices
